captions.text:
Unless you happen to own a ski resort or a
snowplow business or live in the southern

hemisphere, you’re probably tired of seeing
them by now.

But during this seemingly incessant winter,
did you get a chance to take a good, hard
look at a snowflake?

If I asked you to imagine a snowflake, you’d
probably envision something like this -- six

glistening arms radiating out from the center
of a perfectly symmetrical crystal.

And, yeah, some of them look all intricate
and mathematically precise, but they're the

special ones -- the outliers that catch our
attention and end up knitted into our ugly
sweaters.

Usually, though, snowflakes look all lumpy
and awkward. Like this.

And how a snowflake looks -- whether it’s
sweater-worthy or not -- has a whole lot to

do with how it first formed, and what happened
to it after it started to fall.

Snowflakes form when it’s cold enough for
water vapor in the air to change directly
into ice, a process known as deposition.

And when ice starts to crystallize, a snow
crystal is born.

This snow crystal is just the precursor to
the snowflakes you see on the ground, which

are usually made of lots of different snow
crystals clumped together.

Now water tends to form hexagonal crystals
because of the nature of its molecules.

Water, as you know, is H20 that’s one oxygen
and two hydrogens, but it isn’t a linear

molecule -- the hydrogen atoms are crooked
because there are these two unbonded electrons

at the top of the oxygen atom pushing those
hydrogen atoms down so it’s in sort of a
triangular shape.

The oxygen end of the water molecule is slightly
negative in charge, while the hydrogens are
slightly positive.

So, as cold temperatures slow these molecules
down, and they start to coalesce from a gas

into a solid, the positive ends of the molecules
are drawn to the negative ends of others.

And when these vaguely triangular molecules
snap together like this, they typically form
a hexagon.

And this hexagon becomes the center of the
crystal, and the foundation upon which the
rest of the snowflake can grow.

Eventually, when enough water molecules have
come together, and the ice crystal becomes
heavier, it begins to fall.

But here’s the thing: The shape that crystals
can take vary considerably, depending on both
the temperature and humidity in the atmosphere.

Specifically, snowflakes tend to form bigger,
more intricate patterns when more moisture

is in the air, while snowflakes produced in
drier conditions tend to have simpler forms.

Basically, the less water there is in the
air, the less interesting your crystal is
going to be.

For example, the ugly-sweater crystals, which
are often called stellar dendrites, form at

temperatures from -16 to -12 degrees Celsius
-- or sometimes a little warmer -- but only
when the air contains a fair amount of moisture.

These kinds of flakes are relatively rare,
because these conditions are relatively rare.

For one thing, -16 to -12 degrees is a fairly
narrow temperature window.

And, since colder air is usually drier, it’s
even less likely that the air will also have
enough humidity to form dendrites.

Without that humidity, snow crystal shapes
are much less frilly.

In the -16 to -12 range, for example, less
saturated air forms boring, solid, six-sided
plates.

And at many other temperatures, you don’t
even get plates. Above -10 and below -20,

you often see fat, stout kinds of crystals
called columns, or long, spindly needles instead.

But even these relatively dull patterns need
stable, almost laboratory-like conditions

in order to form. And winter weather isn’t
exactly known for its stability.

The fact is, snowflakes actually take their
full shape as they fall.

And as snow crystals fall, the conditions
around them -- like humidity, wind, and temperature
-- also change.

So as each crystal passes through a mix of
different temperatures and moisture levels,

it ends up with different patterns all trying
to form on top of each other -- a kind of

frankenstein’s monster of dendrites and
discs and needles and other shapes.

That’s why the vast majority of snowflakes
are weird, asymmetrical blobs, which have
been politely referred to as irregular crystals.

So, maybe you like them, maybe after this
winter you never want to see them again. But

at least now you know that the stuff you’ve
been shoveling and skiing on didn’t actually
look like what you were wearing on your sweater.

Thank you for watching this episode of SciShow
which was brought to you in part by Audible.com.

Go to Audible.com/SciShow for a free trial
and a free audiobook of your choice. You can

choose from over 150,000 titles, but if you
liked this video, we recommend checking out

"The Story of Earth: The First 4.5 Billion
Years, From Stardust to Living Planet" by

Robert M. Hazen. So go to Audible.com/SciShow
for a free audiobook, and go to YouTube.com/SciShow
for more videos.

comments.author: Evan Haines

comments.text:
Actually, pretty much zero ice crystals initially form from direct 
deposition of water vapor. What you may have meant was homogeneous 
nucleation, or the freezing of a water droplet without contact from any 
other bodies (this occurs only in cirri-form clouds in the upper 
troposphere at temperatures below around -40C). The formation of most can 
be modeled by a "Wegener-Bergeron Process" (
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bergeron_process) which is much more complex.﻿

This is our second year in Tucson that we've had less than 2 weeks of 
winter weather.  Mt. Lemmon Ski Resort didn't even open this year because 
there is no snow at all.  The weather was in the 70's and 80s all winter 
with very little winter rain.  And they say there's no such thing as 
climate change.  Move to AZ and you can live it where you can experience it 
in nice weather.  My daffodils bloomed in February.  Today was 90 degrees 
F.  My roses are all blooming and I have figs on my tree.  The citrus are 
also blooming and it smells like a perfumery in my back yard.  I also have 
amaryllis blooming, they always bloom around Easter/Passover time. ﻿

comments.text:
This winter of 2015 is the third time in my life I have seen a stellar 
dendrites crystalline snowflake. I live in Colorado, where the  phenomena 
that causes them is apparently quite common. See most of our storms come to 
us over Utah and the Great Salt lake, and as we all should know from 9th 
grade science class, salt can cause the temperature of a liquid to drop 
faster and more efficiently than a desalinated liquid. So I guess what I am 
trying to say is...if you knit ugly sweaters or just wish to see these 
pretty little formations of ice...come to Colorado. ;)﻿

comments.text:
+Meg Ashley Even though you have me blocked, someone else may glean

change in temperature experienced by out planet.

It that's the case, then how is it more energy is not being focused on that 
correlation instead of looking at industrial activities?

Anyone?
comments.author: Capt777harris

comments.text:
+Meg Ashley I wasn't looking to voice an opinion.  I am curious why we have 
had a record cold and snow in the light of a warming trend.  An increase in 
temperature, in my opinion, is the result of our star, and not much else.
comments.author: Capt777harris

comments.text:
+Capt777harris If we are going for tautologies, complicated thermodynamic 
systems are complicated.

Temperature oscillates wildly every day, we recently here in Texas had it 
drop by 40 degrees in 12 hours.  That's just weather.

A global temperature increase of 1 degree isn't something you are going to 
detect with your front porch thermometer.  You are over simplifying a 
complex system because you don't want this to be true.  I don't want it to 
be true either, it sucks and is kinda terrifying, but it is what it is and 
I'm not going to let cognitive bias blind me from it.  The vast majority of 
the scientific community now agrees that climate change is occurring, and I 
will trust that evidence over a former meteorologist.

I'm going to stop this conversation now though, because it seems likely 
that you did not post your initial question in an honest effort to learn 
something new.  Instead you seem like you were just looking for a soapbox.
comments.author: Meg Ashley

comments.text:
+Meg Ashley No, it actually doesn't.  When the Earth was warmer the Earth 
was warmer.  That sounds like an obvious "duh" statement, but, if such a 
warming trend were evident, then the ambient temperature would not wildly 
oscillate, and would stay consistent year round.  It hasn't.

The former head meteorologist of Good Morning America tracked solar 
radiation output over X-number of years and has found an amazing corollary 
between the suns output and an increase in mean temperature.

That, as opposed to the exceptionally warm temperatures pre-extinction of 
the dinosaurs.
comments.author: Capt777harris

comments.text:
+Capt777harris Well.  It fits well.  The warming trend idea is not "and 
therefore your zip code will be x degrees warmer year round," it is the 
fact that the average temperature over the entire Earth increases.  So 
while you may be cold right now, you are not feeling the average 
temperature of the Earth, you are feeling your local weather.

Adding energy to a system like this is not going to just flat out up the 
temperature by a certain amount and do nothing else.  Instead, climate 
change is expected to increase the extremes in local weather (exactly what 
you are feeling now, an extreme in weather.)  The southern hemisphere, on 
the other hand, is getting the opposite effect right now, it certainly 
isn't having a record breakingly cold summer.  The increases in temperature 
elsewhere are greater than the decreases in temperature you are feeling 
locally.

It is also worth noting that not all of the increased energy goes into heat 
energy (hence the misleading nature of "global warming.")  Lots of the 
energy goes to increase the kinetic energy of the atmosphere of the Earth 
as a whole, which would mean more churned up air and bigger storms.  The 
kind of churned up air that could, for example, bring cold polar air 
further south than it normally goes (polar vortex style.)

So in summary, the record breaking winter fits well with the predictions of 
global climate change.
comments.author: Meg Ashley

comments.text:
+Meg Ashley Okay, miss Ashley; Hank and Gang, how does this record breaking 
winter and record snowfall gybe with "global total atmospheric energy 
increase, to include kinetic energy as well as temperature effects"?

There you go  :)

p.s. in light of a supposed "warming trend."
comments.author: Capt777harris

comments.text:
It is not "global warming" it is "climate change."  Global warming is an 
incorrect and misleading term which the scientific community has largely 
discarded.  The idea is that any complicated system will have complicated 
reactions when there is a bunch of extra energy dumped into it, as weather 
and climate are very different things.  In fact a better term might be 
"global total atmospheric energy increase, to include kinetic energy as 
well as temperature effects" but that doesn't roll off the tongue well.
comments.author: Meg Ashley
